frontmatter.title: Definition of Free and Bound Variables

mainmatter.p:
The set of free variables of an \mathcal L-formula is defined inductively as follows.
The set of free variables of an atomic formula is the set of all variables appearing in the formula.
\mathrm {var}( \neg A) = \mathrm {var}(A), where A is a formula.
\mathrm {var}(A \lor B) = \mathrm {var}(A) \cup \mathrm {var}(B), where A and B are formulas.
\mathrm {var}(A \land B) = \mathrm {var}(A) \cup \mathrm {var}(B), where A and B are formulas.
\mathrm {var}( \exists v \, A) = \mathrm {var}(A) \setminus \set v, where A is a formula and v is a variable.
\mathrm {var}( \forall v \, A) = \mathrm {var}(A) \setminus \set v, where A is a formula and v is a variable.
If a variable appears in a formula but is not free, then it is called bound.
Given a language \mathcal {L}, an \mathcal {L}-formula is defined inductively as follows:
If \phi is an \mathcal {L}-atomic formula then \phi is a formula
If \phi and \psi are both formulas, then \neg \phi, \phi \land \psi, and \phi \lor \phi are formulas, where \lor , \neg , \land are the usual logical connectives
If \phi is a formula, then \exists x \phi and \forall x \phi are formulas, where \exists and \forall are quantifiers
An \mathcal L-formula is a sentence when its set of free variables is empty.
